title: Sony Xperia Z3 UK SIM-Free Smartphone - Black
review_text: Having had my iPhone 4s for three years, I opted to go with the Sony Xperia Z3 compact. While I was interested in a larger screen, I felt the iPhone 6 had become too large and almost unpocketable (and add to that its bendability). Having recently compared both phones, I personally find the Z3 compact much nicer to hold - the plastic/rubber edge and the fact that it is a little bit thicker means it is much less likely to slip out of your hand if you're not using a case. The phone is roughly the same size as the iPhone 5/5s, but slightly wider.Making the switch from IOS to Android has taken some getting used to, but within a few days I have managed to set up the phone to my liking. What I dislike is the bloatware installed by Sony, but fortunately you are able to hide away most of this software - the majority of which I won't use. The camera and Walkman apps are good though and I appreciate the ability to shoot in manual mode and change settings. Other review sites have said that the iPhone 6 camera is considerably better than the Sony Z3, but as I have a proper camera I only sporadically use a phone camera and I feel it would be up to the task if I did happen to come across a must-shoot opportunity. The wide angle of the lens is definitely appreciated.Another big attraction of the phone is its battery life. This had been particularly poor for me on the iPhone 4s and I believe it remains the case with the iPhone 6 (with Apple favouring the thinness of the device over better battery life). As a light/medium user I can easily make the Z3 compact last for two days with still 25% to spare.I am very satisfied with the screen and given that it is a 4.6" screen I am glad that they have gone for 720p rather than full HD (this likely to have a negative impact on the battery). It is a very fast phone and you do not notice any lag at all. Definitely a step up from the 4S, which has become quite laggy for me.Taking into account its specs - which are on a par or in fact slightly better than the iPhone 6 - and its price point, I think the Z3 compact is a no brainer.

title: Sony Xperia Z3 UK SIM-Free Smartphone - Black
review_text: I've had this a little while now but had wanted to wait for a few charge cycles and a few weeks of use before writing a review.I'm sure that a question that will be high on people's list when it comes to this phone is whether or not it really last 2 days. The long and the short answer is yes. The least I have got from it is just over 38 hours or so and this is when I was using it constantly- Kindle, Audible, Spotify, Camera and general fiddling to get used to the phone. On the current cycle, with a bit less use but still some tinkering and watching of videos on Youtube etc, it's at 2 days, and 9 hours- admittedly it's on 1% and about to die but I think that as smart phones go, with the specs the Z3 has, this is impressive. I have my phone on Stamina mode and wifi only activates when it picks up a known network which also helps with battery consumption.Have a nano sim ready so you can use it straight away. I knew it took a nano sim so I had that before the phone itself arrived. Easy to get it swapped over. I am with O2 but I would guess the process would be similar with other networks.I had wanted the aqua phone but was not prepared to pay the full price from Carphone Warehouse and I had a number of amazon vouchers to use.I may compromise and get the aqua phone cover when it is released but happy with the cover I have at the moment and the aqua phone cover is pricey.I agree with the bloatware comments but having come from a Samsung, I can't say this bothers me too much- I just ignore it.I have not experienced any over heating at all. Any warmth I have felt I think has more to do with my own body heat when I hold it for prolonged periods of time than anything else.Sound quality is impressive from the phones speakers and also with earphones plugged in. No tinniness at all and a good bass. I had an S3 mini previously and it blows this out of the water when it comes to sound quality which doesn't surprise me in the slightest.The camera is incredible. It's fast and takes incredible shots. So much so that a friend of mine I was chatting to via what's app and sending images to asked what phone I had as it took amazing photos.I haven't noticed any lag at all. It is extremely fast. I hit a key and it does what I want it to do immediately. No momentary pause- just straight to it.The screen is nice and sharp. If you would like a screen protector (I highly suggest you do for some extra protection), I recommend the same ones as Beanie: 6x Savvies SU75 UltraClear Screen Protector for Sony Xperia Z3 Compact D5803. The phone itself is super sleek and great for use in one hand. For me it was never a question of going for the Z3 over the Z3C as I just don't like big phones and the marginally better screen and slightly higher specs were not enough to entice me.For a bit of extra grip, I'd recommend one of the silicon phone cases (Yousave Accessories Sony Xperia Z3 Compact Case Black Silicone X-Line Cover). The smoothness of the phone did make me paranoid I would drop it but I don't think I would have done.The silicon case adds a bit of grip that eradicates this feeling without adding bulk to the phone and detracting from how streamline it is.I have purchased a magnetic USB charger for less than Â£3 from ebay that works a treat. I don't feel that the flap over the USB socket would wear out but for Â£3, better safe than sorry.I honestly can't fault it. I tend to take very good care of my electronic gadgets. I have friends and family that just have to look at their phone and it gets scuffed! I can see me having this for a good few years.5 stars after 2 weeks of use but should any issues/faults crop up I will most definitely be back to update this review.*****UPDATE 20/10/2015*****I lost my phone and got a replacement through my insurance in January. I wanted to update this review to say that the headphone jack has started to play up. As long as I keep the phone still and don't knock the headphones close to where they are plugged in, it's fine but if you do knock it, which is easy to do, the sound cuts out. This is annoying as I use Spotify a lot to listen to music. I imagine I have just been unlucky as I went 9 month with this particular phone with no issues but wanted to update my review accordingly.

title: Sony Xperia 10 6 Inch 21:9 Full HD+ display Android 9 UK SIM-Free Smartphone with 3GB RAM and 64GB Storage - Black
review_text: Been a sony phone user for 12 years, always had dependable cheap phones. This is the first time they have let me down! Bought as a replacement for my last Sony phone that lasted over 2 years of pretty rough life as I used to work as a welder. High temperatures, sparks and spatter, being dropped and all. It eventaully had an occasional screen fault that meant 1/3 times the phone didn't respond to touch. The battery also wasn't lasting as long as it used to so I decided it was time for a replacement.As soon as this phone arrived I knew it would be a disappointment. Something inside the phone would rattle/shake as you picked the phone up. The touch screen was worse than my very broken old phone, and the battery didn't last as long either!I thought I'd give it a few months but the frustration continued. Regular crashing and all sorts of other annoyances made me consider going back to my old very broken phone. I've now been forced to go back to my old phone as the charging port on the new one overheated and melted, meaning it's useless. Will try to get a warrantee claim in, but won't hold my breath!How have Sony even been able to release a phone this useless?

review_text: I got this phone because I didn't like samsung due to battery deterioration. At a glance, the phone was amazing. It was amazing for a few months too. Then the problems occurred. When I plugged the phone in to charge it would go through a reboot cycle and reboot until it overheated or drained the battery. Took it in for repair. The cpu fried every component in the phone. It went on to take 3 more repairs in two weeks. It worked for another 6 months and now it's doing the same thing again. Don't buy this phone.Good points:Very slimVery responsive5g readyGreat for taking photosConsOverheatsBack everything up or you'll lose it eventuallyVideo calls will overheat your phoneThe headphone jack is faultyCharging port sensors are bugged

title: Sony Xperia 10 IV - 6 Inch 21:9 Wide OLED display - Triple Lens Camera - 3.5 mm audio jack - 5000mAh - 161g - SIM free - Dual SIM hybrid - Purple
review_title: The Best Moby Iâ€™ve Ever Owned!.
review_text: I had wanted a Sony Xperia for AGES.My last phone was a Google Pixel, and it was good until I dropped it,completely smashing the screen.After that it was obvious it wasnâ€™t working like before.Of course,everyone was saying ,get an iPhone.But have you seen the prices for a  new 6â€iPhone?I loved the Sony brand,always have and knew they are a reputable company.I didnâ€™t have the money to buy a brand new Xperia,so I bought a used one aÂ£100 cheaper,as it supposedly had a number of scratches and dodgy screen.I more than likely shouldnâ€™t be saying this,but they sent me out a brand new one!.I was over the moon with it!.Not a mark on itThe only thing missing was the earphones Theyâ€™d told me that the charger was missing too.but it was in the box Perfect in every way.Wonderful phone and works like a charm.But,like everything.it has a downside.The camera isnâ€™t that good.I have a much cheaper Â£200 Honor Magiclite that takes much more wonderful photos than this.And,although it states quite clearly the size.I wish it was bigger and wider.Itâ€™s a very narrow phone.But  perfect in every other way.Still canâ€™t believe I got a split new one!.Thank God I didnâ€™t buy the Samsung Galaxy I was also looking at.Press that Buy Now button itâ€™s worth it. Enjoy!.

title: Sony Xperia 10 IV - 6 Inch 21:9 Wide OLED display - Triple Lens Camera - 3.5 mm audio jack - 5000mAh - 161g - SIM free - Dual SIM hybrid - Purple
review_text: I didn't want to spend Â£700+ on a high end phone but you definitely get what you pay for. I got this to have a better battery life and the battery life is INCREDIBLE over setup it only went down 3% or so over some 2h. The phone itself felt nice and was good to use, but very different to my Samsung s10e and I returned this because of the camera. I didn't think I would care that much but it just isn't good it isn't sharp and the front camera was dreadful, so if you want a decent camera don't compromise! Also didn't have a gallery or notes app which I know you can sort by getting one but it seems a bit weird not having one already there idk? But yes, definitely not a bad phone at all just not what I was looking for.

title: Sony Xperia 10 II Android Smartphone - 6.0 Inch 21:9 Wide FHD+ OLED display - Triple Lens Camera - IP65/68 Rating Water Resistance - 4 GB RAM - 128 GB Storage â€“ Single Sim, Black
review_text: This sony phone is a great all rounder. Easy to use and light in weight, the battery life is really good (charged it once in 3 days) it also has a stamina mode that you can set to activate when the battery % drops to a certain level, making it last even longer.less scrolling up and down with the long screen easily fitting the keyboard and chat boxes at the same time with the likes of whatsapp and facebook.Great camera, great screen, nice and loud ear piece when on a call. even a 3.5mm jack socket for headphones that a lot of other phone makers have stopped doing.For the price of Â£320 its well worth it.

title: Sony Xperia 10 II Android Smartphone - 6.0 Inch 21:9 Wide FHD+ OLED display - Triple Lens Camera - IP65/68 Rating Water Resistance - 4 GB RAM - 128 GB Storage â€“ Single Sim, Black
review_text: I bought this to replace a Sony Xperia XZ1.  This is my first glass bodied phone.  It's incredibly slippery.  I now appreciate why half the population owning mid and high end smartphones have cracked screens.  So after initial inspection and set up I put it back in the box and ordered a gel case and since it arrived and was fitted the phone is as good to hold as any cheap plastic phone!The good stuff:  nice display, very legible.  I'd have preferred a 16:9 ratio but the fashion gods and their marketing devils don't cater to normal people or reality.  It's *just* compact enough to use one handed by a 5'10 male with  average size hands. The fingerprint sensor is just like on the older XZ series, i.e. ideal.  The volume buttons are in the right place.  The sound quality with suitable earphones is impeccable., though the output impedance seems to be somewhat higher than 1 so you might get an uneven response with balanced armature  IEMs.  The GPS is excellent, really fast & accurate.  All the networking stuff including NFC & Bluetooth works perfectly.  Battery life is certainly better than the old XZ series.Sony's version of Android is almost identical to Google's so everything works just how you'd expect. No pointless duplication like Samsung and no crazy menus or annoying bugs like Xiaomi.  It's very slick.It's waterproof!  My old XZ1 is also waterproof and this has saved the day in the past with a very unfortunate bathroom related incident.  Uuugh.It accepts my 1TB Sandisk microSD card and works perfectly with it.Call quality is fine, no problems at all.I'm not sure about the camera yet.  It seems very good but Sony haven't packed this line of phones with their excellent Album app or 3D image creator and their other excellent photo related stuff.  I'm finding using the camera a bit slow compared to the XZ1.The phone is getting regular security patches.  How long this will last is uncertain.  When I bought my XZ1 Sony had promised two full Android upgrades and security support but they disgracefully reneged on this after the first full upgrade.  I stuck with Sony specifically because by buying this model retail instead of from a network, I get a phone with unlockable bootloader and support of the Sony Open Devices Project so it won't become redundant after getting its final official upgrades/updates.Overall it's a nice phone that is just compact enough for people who really don't want a two handed behemoth.  It's very practical due to being waterproof, has everything you need for Google Pay, doesn't have any irritating bugs or "extra features" and does everything very well.  Stick a gel case on it so it doesn't shoot out of your hand like a bar of soap and it's very easy to live with.

title: Sony Xperia 10 II Android Smartphone - 6.0 Inch 21:9 Wide FHD+ OLED display - Triple Lens Camera - IP65/68 Rating Water Resistance - 4 GB RAM - 128 GB Storage â€“ Single Sim, Black
review_title: Decent phone for the reasonable price
review_text: It's a good looking phone. Colours, especially black, look much better than on Xperia X which I previously owned. It is slightly longer than Xperia X, despite having 21:9 format.Sony didn't disappoint with battery life, it can last even up to 5 days ! I don't play games much, the phone is used mostly for calling, texting and internet browsing. It may require some customisation though,  which means configuring apps to stop running in background if they not in use.Camera quality is quite good, although I don't use it very often.Almost clear Android , with very few manufacturer apps, was one of the reason I decided to stay with Sony mobiles.Overall, quite good device with long battery life.

title: Sony Xperia 10 II Android Smartphone - 6.0 Inch 21:9 Wide FHD+ OLED display - Triple Lens Camera - IP65/68 Rating Water Resistance - 4 GB RAM - 128 GB Storage â€“ Single Sim, Black
review_text: Best phone I've ever had.I've always overlooked Sony in favour of Apple and Samsung, so I thought I'd give Sony a try this time and I'm so glad I did, its spot on.The slim form feels really comfortable in the hand and the wide-screen is brilliant for watching movies.As you would expect from Sony, the build quality is second to none.The high waterproof rating means I have no concerns if it gets wet.The battery life is fantastic, I easily get through a full day with moderate use.The fingerprint reader is quick and hasn't let me down once.I know the camera gets mixed reviews but I've found that by tweaking the settings in manual mode I've been able to get excellent results.The OS is pretty much stock Android so there's no bloatwear slowing the phone and cluttering up the storage.At Â£319, this phone is a bargain.

title: Sony Xperia 10 II Android Smartphone - 6.0 Inch 21:9 Wide FHD+ OLED display - Triple Lens Camera - IP65/68 Rating Water Resistance - 4 GB RAM - 128 GB Storage â€“ Single Sim, Black
review_text: Iâ€™ve had a number of Xperia phones and the, stupidly, bought a Google Pixel (tons of bloat ware and poor performance). So itâ€™s great to be back with Sony. The overall performance is astounding for the price. Only negative so far is the video camera function seems to have issues with constant adjusting of focus and light.

title: Sony Xperia 10 II Android Smartphone - 6.0 Inch 21:9 Wide FHD+ OLED display - Triple Lens Camera - IP65/68 Rating Water Resistance - 4 GB RAM - 128 GB Storage â€“ Single Sim, Black
review_text: This is a surprisingly good phone for the price. Performance is snappy, finger-print reader generally very good (have clean finger ;)) and no real problems at all. Like the thinner, taller form factor and it is light and very pocketable. 2 sim slots/1 sim and one micro SD slot is very handyNo real obvious cons, although the fingerprint reader was fiddly to set up. This was a downgrade from an iPhone 12 pro and I haven't regretted it, considering it's a third of the price.

title: Sony Xperia 10 II Android Smartphone - 6.0 Inch 21:9 Wide FHD+ OLED display - Triple Lens Camera - IP65/68 Rating Water Resistance - 4 GB RAM - 128 GB Storage â€“ Single Sim, Black
review_title: Would recommend as a mid range phone.
review_text: Love this phone. Was purchased to replace an old Sony Z 3. Everything about is great. However the comments about the camera being slow taking pictures in poor light are true. This is the only bug I can find. The phone is slim so typing is a little awkward. You can however turn phone sideways then typing is a doddle.

title: Sony Xperia L1 SIM-Free 16GB Smartphone - Black
review_text: I like Sony products so decided to take the plunge with the entry level Xperia (so the camera has an inferior lens) but I wasn't really bothered about that. Anyway, the phone is great and having used Windows Phone for years I was coming over to Android and the OS on the whole is better in the sense that it is far less sluggish. I'm now able to complete tasks such as web browsing much quicker than I could have with my previous phone.The most impressive feature of the phone besides the design (which I really like with the feeling of the back cover which is less likely to slip out of your hand although I'd recommend a case), is the battery life where the phone will last for days if not heavily used. Even if you watch some videos it can last for quite a while although it depends on how long you're watching videos. If there's a negative of the Xperia it is that it's stuffed with useless apps that are hard to remove. The default space is almost taken up by 50% with apps but you can always upgrade the memory if needed.If you're looking for a mid-range phone that doesn't have too many advanced features you will be happy with the Xperia. It does the job or at least it does in what I'm seeking in a phone which is the basics such as calls and texts with a few extras. It can do anything pricier competitors can but just less of it or at an inferior standard such as with photos. If you need a phone for pictures you're much better with the more expensive model but for everyone else it will work just fine.

title: Sony Xperia L1 SIM-Free 16GB Smartphone - Black
review_text: Sony L1 unlocked single sim phone purchased for my hubby after a year of trying to convince him he needed a new phone to replace his old Windows Phone which was on its way out with regards to support/updates and on charge more than off charge!  This phone seemed a good beginners phone for someone not familiar with Android and frightened of it.  It also gave me the opportunity to familiarise him with my XZ Premium phone on the basics before the L1 arrived.  After not wanting to change his phone ever because he liked the one he already had, after only a few weeks he now says the L1 is the best phone he's had and wishes he'd changed sooner.  There you go, sometimes you just need to take the plunge.As another reviewer pointed out, this phone does take a nano sim card, so those who purchase this phone, if not already using a nano sim, need to contact their Service Provider to supply a new.  Having read details and reviews we were ready and waiting with a new sim card before the phone arrived so we could set up straight away.Having purchased another Sony phone in the last year, it seemed pretty straight forward.  No info in the box, but that is quite common these days, but the Xperia Assistant on the phone directs as part of the set-up process.  It does tell you you can transfer all your old phone stuff from Windows Phones to Android or from Android-to-Android.  However the option to transfer from Windows was fiddly as not an automatic transfer;  I had to do a bit of Google research on how to do this successfully.  Thankfully we will never go back to using a Windows phone so will never be a problem again the hard work is done now.The phone doesn't have a lot of memory and it is taken up with apps that you may not need (and can only disable and not remove), but I've just put in the memory card from the previous phone and bulked it up.For beginners, you can customise it so everything you use is on the main screen.The phone comes pre-loaded with free AVG anti-virus, though we chose to boost this up with a paid-for app similar to our laptop and tablet as you can never be too careful.Not being a high phone user the battery will lasts anywhere between 2-3 days.  The charger that came in the box consists of a USB cable that connects to a separate plug.  So you can use the USB to plug into your laptop and charge via that if it is switched on, or alternatively you can put the plug on one end of the USB cable and use a regular wall plug socket.Switch on/off is quick and the operating is pretty good too and doesn't seem to have any lags.  Surfing the internet and opening webpages is quick.As it is more of an entry level phone, there isn't a scanner on or finger recognition (nor does it come with any earphones/buds).  You get what you pay for, and for most people they don't really want all the fancy additions.  The camera pixels forward face and back are very good.  There does seem to be a  bit of a delay when pressing the button to take a photo and it actually taking the photo.  My XZ is the same so may be a common and normal for all Sony phones across their whole range.  It does not cause a problem once you know and adapt.Phone size isn't too small or too big and fits in the hand comfortably.  Screen is very clear and the colours are excellent.  I purchased the OMOTON Screen Protectors for this phone to prevent damage.  A must-have if you drop your phone.  The tempered glass of the protectors mean not only do they fit snug on the screen, the smooth glass ensures that you can glide across the screen without any drag or sticking (no need for a stylus).  Combined this set-up with a Terrepin Black/Tan full case (all purchased from Amazon) to make the phone safe from damage.Overall the phone is easy to use.  From out of the box to in-use it was approximately 1 hour.  All the apps required were downloaded from PlayStore, email set up, personalisation, etc.  Had I not had the issue with transferring from Windows and having to Google the procedure, it wouldn't have taken that long at all.Based on my experience with hubby's phone.  If I could turn the clock back for myself, I probably wouldn't have been a phone-snob and bought my XZ Premium model and would have purchased this L1 instead as it has all the features I need and excellent value for money.I understand that this phone is being discontinued.  So if anyone is looking for a phone that doesn't want all the fancy stuff, but good in every other respect, go for this phone while it is still available.  I don't think you will be disappointed.

title: Sony Xperia L1 SIM-Free 16GB Smartphone - Black
review_title: Flagship looks for a budget price
review_text: Brought this on prime day, i needed a spare phone plus being a dual sim , makes it Evan better for when i am on holiday. I am currently using a sony xz and in our household we have a z5 and a xz premium. The 1st impressions of this phone , are positive the phone feels solid and well built it actually feels more expensive then its price dictates .I have compared it to my xz which cost Â£500 , for phone that costs 169 its fairly good and does most tasks well , multitasking , camera, screen display are above average. The 5.5 display produces decent quality pictures and colors , the phone is quite responsive and only slightly lags when multitasking,  For me the xz is still way ahead in terms of performance, the camera is average but for Â£169 this good value, if i didn't use a high end phone then i could quite easily get use to this phone.  If your on a budget your getting big screen android phone with android  nougat for a 3rd of the price of a flagship, yes the xz and xz premium are way ahead in terms of performance but you have to pay for it , but the L1 gives you a great experience for those on atight budget.

title: Sony Xperia L1 SIM-Free 16GB Smartphone - Black
review_title: A good budget phone in general let down in the details.
review_text: I have had the Xperia L1 for around a month now. The general performance when running apps is reasonably slick, but I've noticed a few annoying quirks as time has gone on.The bluetooth fails to reconnect with paired devices about 50% of the time which means re-pairing with the hands free kit most days.My ear will often activate functions on the screen mid-call. I actually deleted an important voicemail by accident this way! After numerous other smartphones never having this type of issue this was really annoying.The camera functions are disappointing when compared with my last phone which was also a budget model (Samsung Galaxy Core Prime).Finally, this is the first smartphone I've had which does not have a physical 'home' button and I'm surprised how such a small feature proves so annoying.In summary, the phone will probably be fine for someone who wants a cheap, slick smartphone, but if you make a lot of calls it might be best to look at the alternatives.

title: Sony Xperia XA UK SIM-Free Smartphone - Black
review_title: Looking for a premium smartphone that won't break the bank?
review_text: Positives: I've downloaded between 50/60 apps since I've had this phone a week or so now and still all functions are slick. Very  premium Iphone feel to this product when you swipe and move between apps and functions which to me just oozes in class. The screen is extended but not visibly wrapped around edges like galaxy S6/7 but enough to extend field of view and add an extra quality to this product. The 5 inch screen really makes the phone feel like just holding a screen a times as other than on/off aux and volumne buttons down the side all the functions like home screen button are in the software.  The phone is big enough to watch now tv or netflix from but still maintains that pocket size something I always look for in a mobile.  A back high quality video and camera and a passable front camera is making me consider why the hell I bought a Â£300 digital camera recently, there was just no point in having both . The connectivity and communication between apps/ emails and general day to day functioning of this phone is great and couldn't hope for more so far although its only been a few days since I've connected it up to my emails, social media's etc but owning a ps4 means I can take full advantage of a neat little PS4 app which links my phone to the system and visa versa.Negatives: I've only had the phone a few days so the negatives so far around limited to what I already know about the product. I know at some point I will need a micro sd card, I also know at some point it will crack, lets face it they all do so defiantly need to get a casing and a screen protector to delay the inevitable. The back of the phone is liable to finger print smudging buts that probably because this isn't a fully metallic back probably Sony cutting costs, but its still a premium feel and look none the less. The placement of the function buttons on side of phone is lower and will take some getting used to and the power button sticks out slightly, not had a problem yet but I Imagine it could at some point pocket-turn off. I'm not convinced the battery life is all that but I was excessive downloading apps yesterday and had 10's or so running in background. It does however charge very quickly especially with their quick charger gimmick which takes just 10 minutes or so to get to 50%.All in all I think I saved Â£350 or so in not getting an Iphone. But you get what you pay for, this a premium feeling phone with powerful specs/HD and actually it looks a lot better in person than the picture gives it credit for. But be realistic with these reviews as it is at the more affordable end of the smartphone range but I could easily pass this off for a Â£400 mobile to friends (if I cared that much) and for a simpleton like me this handy peice of kit at  a 3 star price is leaps and bounds ahead of my old smartphone from 2014 even running from a similar android system. I've added two recent photos to this review from the back camera. Fingers crossed I have the same views in 6 months time!

title: Sony Xperia XA UK SIM-Free Smartphone - Black
review_text: Sony Xperia XA UK SIm-Free Smartphone is one excellent phone which not only sounds great but also with the added advantage it looks good too.The Sony has a long thin screen which allows the phone to be capable for good visual qualities which is the main bonus point when I was looking to purchase a new phone.  Everything on the screen is ideal and easy to use.I have fitted a Micro SD card which provided me with much needed extra memory which I would also recommend as with the many apps this phone can use because of the excellent and fast processor.Everything about this phone is First class and from the workings of the phone to the actual attractiveness of the phone, this is certainly a phone which stands out in the crowd.Why I like this phone is mainly the ease of use, everything about it was straightforward.  It has some excellent apps which come under the heading "Introduction to Sony" along with many more apps exclusively for the Sony Xperia range which provide many hours of fun and relaxation.I love this phone for the main reason it is first class throughout, and that includes the look and workmanship of the phone.  Everything about the phone is quality,The one main item I love about the phone is how quick I can get the camera to take a photograph, it is the simple task of pressing the small button required and I am ready to take a photograph which is especially important when those moments surprise us and I know it is a moment I want to photograph.  In the past when I would take a photo using my Smartphone by the time I got the phone working the moment would be long past.  The photographs are exceptional and this is another reason I love this phone is how clear and wonderful they are, with the added advantage with a swipe of the finger I can go from still photographs to video in seconds which makes this phone special.There is an app called the Album which holds all those memories and with the added advantage this has so many hidden extras I do not believe I will ever get to know them all!I love this phone and I am so pleased with my purchase, from the audio qualities, the ease of use and the presentation this is a phone which will hold it's own in the Smartphone world.I am happy to recommend the Sony Xperia XA UK SIM-Free Smartphone(White) as a top quality phone which comes top of the class in every category which matters to me as a customer who certainly needs a phone which works with speed and top quality sounds throughout.

title: Sony Xperia X 32GB SIM Free Smartphone - Black
review_title: Top Quality as you expect from Sony
review_text: Up to the usual high standards you expect from Sony. This is a superbly designed smartphone with metal case and curved-edge screen - similar to the iPhone 6/7 and Samsung S7. It's larger than the former though and fits well in the hand while still having a bright, clear 5-inch screen. The product photos are a little confusing though because that strange lock-screen is actually just a glimpse of the sideways motion the unlocking swipe takes, and the colourful paintbrush swirls are the wallpaper underneath (easily changed).The instructions say charge for 30-mins before first use, so I did. And if it's like mine then proceeds to update itself, all the way up to Android 7 Nougat.In use the phone is responsive and handles everything thrown at it. I've read reviews of the heat generated by the latest Sony's but have to say I haven't noticed it. That big initial upgrading - which overall took quite a while - didn't make the phone any warmer than any other I've had. In fact I'd say it became only slightly warm. Certainly nothing out of the ordinary.So far I'm down to 50% after that original charge 5 days ago, so there's no battery problem either. True I don't sit glued to it all day like a teenager and turn it off at night. From previous experience of other phones I'm quite happy.The box is Sony's new style - less flat and more boxy. You get the phone, a USB cable and adaptive fast charger (UCH10) and a couple of leaflets. That's all. So no earphones.The SIM is a Nano-sized one and it fits in a single pull out tray alongside a memory card if you choose to use one.On Sony's web-site you'll find a full PDF manual and the "Xperia Companion" desktop software for both Windows and macOS if you'd like to use that. For Windows users only there's the "Media Go" music and video player available too. An alternative to the like of iTunes etc. None of this is needed though.All in all the phone doesn't disappoint. I've owned Sony phones before and they just keep getting better. I've owned iPhones too but keep coming back to Sony.A good buy from a quality brand.

title: Sony Xperia X 32GB SIM Free Smartphone - Black
review_text: Received this mobile phone promptly, just what I wanted the Sony phones are well made .had a M2 before but as with most phones the mic started to go,the only thing that I can't adjust too is when you start up you have to swipe the screen to the left, I only had to swipe to the right.the camera is very good, nice clear photos.the Battery is better than the M2 I had previously. I have now gone over to 4G as well with my provider so todate I have had no problems.

title: Sony Xperia X 32GB SIM Free Smartphone - Black
review_title: Great phone. I would definitely recommend.
review_text: I originally had a Samsung J5 but had to buy another phone as the internal memory was only 4GB and it started to get full pretty quickly even though I only purchased it 6 months previously. I looked through all the reviews of different makes of phones on Amazon. The internal memory needed to be larger I decided on 32GB. I looked at many models but read a review of this Xperia model. Many reviewers said that it was a lovely phone. The camera was good - I watched a film on YouTube about this phone and people said that the camera was adequate I didn't need a top of the range one as I don't take my phone on holiday - I take my fuji camera with me.I originally didn't think I needed the news application that was already downloaded on the phone but now I am continually reading this as I like to keep abreast of what is happening in the world.I love the fact that you can change the lock screen and home screen wallpapers. I have downloaded two wallpaper apps -  Bagrounds and HAD wallpapers  along with Zedge. The Zedge app is brilliant as the Expedia X phone allows you to change the icons using Zedge like for example, the original icons the camera, calendar, phone and the message app to name but a few. You can install another weather app even though there one already installed. The applications that are already installed on the phone fresh out of the box can not be removed but can be disabled which is better than most phones of this price It is fine for me but it would be even better if you could completely uninstall them. It does free up space though.Playstore is of course installedâ€‹. The home screen panel takes about of getting used to as you can add more panels and it works slightly different to the Samsung phones  it I feel it is better as you can change the order of your applications to suit you.There are other applications that are pre-installed that I have never come across before such as TrackID which tells you what you are listening to. What's New gives you more theme to download. The Lounge is worth keeping as it gives you competitions to complete.It has it's own protection AVG where you can scan it for threats I'm not to sure if it runs out and you have to buy it I have yet to look at that - I have  security on my Acer Tablet and I can add my phone to it. AVG is a good security app so that is up to you if you keep it.I really like this phone I would definitely recommend anyone to buy it. I did intend to buy another Samsung but as there was trouble with their phone batteries I decided to go with a different brand and I am glad I did. This  Xperia is lovely. I did look at other models of the  Xperia range but this model came with the right specifications that I needed.

title: Sony Xperia X 32GB SIM Free Smartphone - Black
review_text: Wow what a phone its a quality well built device and one of the best phones I've used and I've had a few, using the phone is smooth no lag at all OS seems to been very well optimised by Sony, camera is great and is more than capable of taking some cracking shots. We all moan about price I paid under Â£400 and for me its very good value if you look at how the phone is built, looks and performs.I've looked at all the low reviews on the various review sites out their in the www and I have no Idea how they can come up with scores of 2 and 3 stars out of 5 this phone is a 4 all day long, far better phone experience that with the Galaxy S6, S6 Edge, Nexus 5x.Anyone who gives a low review of this phone clearly does not own it.ProBuild qualityScreen bright and hi resNo lagFront facing speakers and headphone socket on the top of the phone where it should beCrystal Clear earphone/mic when taking phone callsFantastic audio quality through Sony MDR-EX110LP Deep Bass EarphonesCamera and dedicated camera buttonCon'sNo Earphones included

title: Sony Xperia Z5, all carriers, 32gb, Compact SIM-Free Smartphone (UK Version) - Graphite Black
review_text: Superb phone. Very, very fast. Of course it puts heat out when you are first booting it - it's massively powerful in a tiny package. Tough and waterproof. Dropped it a bunch of times onto tiles - with a hard shell on because I am not stupid and I keep a case on it all the time - with no problems with screen breakage or any kind of damage. Sony make very tough phones in a sleek, even pretty form. Fingerprint sensor works great and I remember my PIN as an alternative security because why wouldn't you? With the latest Android it's easy to turn off all the annoying Sony garbage if you don't want it - personally I really appreciate the Walkman music player and I'm sure other people would like at least some of the other guff Sony load for your convenience. My mates all have Apple phones and they all think this phone is nicer to look at and hold. What more can I say, buy one.

title: Sony Xperia Z5, all carriers, 32gb, Compact SIM-Free Smartphone (UK Version) - Graphite Black
review_text: For me, I don't want a big screen, I want a pocketable smart phone with the specs of the top models. The Xperia Z5 Compact is pretty much just that. This Z5 Compact replaced my Z1 Compact so I'm sold on how great this range is. Why?- Great size, fits in pockets with ease, and can be used with one hand.- Performance is snappy and doesn't get bogged down with lots of apps left open.- Camera is decent; it might have 23 megapixels, in intelligent auto, you get 20 MP (although by default it's set to 8) but images can get noisy indoors.- Waterproof doesn't mean you have to go swimming with it (although I have), but even for day to day things like when my toddler grabs my phone with sticky fingers I can run it under the tap rather than getting my knickers in a knot.

title: Sony Xperia Z5, all carriers, 32gb, Compact SIM-Free Smartphone (UK Version) - Graphite Black
review_title: Like Z3 compact in many respects.
review_text: Sony do not get enough recognition they do great smartphones with best Android battery life it is just their cameras always suffer. Under medium conditions nearly get 2 days battery. The cam is a little better than Z3 compact but still can have over sharpening oil painting look.There is plenty of customisation and every now and then video things pop up and the phone has stitched photos/vids into a mini movie type thing. It is solid built 8/10 audio quality through headphones and will not really drive high impedance earphones, it only has medium volume with my 32 ohm TT-Pod earbuds,earpiece is bit tinny in phone calls. Flash is same as Z3C not that bright. Screen detailed colourful but only giving it 6/10 for screen legibility in sunlight outdoors.Overall competent, sturdy, stable good battery life phone.

title: Sony Xperia Z5, all carriers, 32gb, Compact SIM-Free Smartphone (UK Version) - Graphite Black
review_title: Great phone - spoiled by overheating - wouldn't recommend
review_text: Absolutely great phone, size, features, camera - if it didn't get warm enough to toast marshmallows on.During 1st time setup it got very hot while downloading all the apps and syncing contacts etc - I could forgive that, it's not really normal everyday behaviour. But during normal browsing/usage it gets noticeably warm and when I tried a 4k video (once I got past the "This device might overheat and shutdown" warning) it got really warm, really quickly. A browse of internet and there are a lot of sites complaining about the Qualcomm Snapdragon 810 processor getting hot. I'd read a few reviews that mentioned this but thought it was for heavy download/gaming - not what I'd planned to use phone for. But it even gets warm in just general everyday use.It's not going to burn you or set fire to your house but the constant heating/cooling cycles and the device running hot will not be great for component stability & therefore long-term viability of a >Â£400 phone. I decided to ditch it and get my money back before that could become my problem. As a chip design engineer myself, kind of amazed they are shipping regardless. Don't know what to go for now, most other recent Androids are enormous.

title: Sony Xperia Z5, all carriers, 32gb, Compact SIM-Free Smartphone (UK Version) - Graphite Black
review_text: I'm on my second Z5C, the first one had awful blur on the left-hand side of photos so it was returned and a replacement sent from Amazon.  The second phone still had blur, but not quite as bad (still left-side).  Unfortunately the 2nd phone also suffers from a bright spot in the middle of the screen.  This defect is very subtle and only apparent when scrolling text on a white background, but once noticed is quite annoying.  I really wanted a smaller phone with a decent camera, so with the market not exactly flush with other possibilities I decided to keep the phone (albeit not perfect).  I wouldn't recommend the phone based on my experience, but if you find a good example without screen or camera issues I'm sure you will be happy with it, as performance, battery overall build is good.

title: Sony Xperia L2 5.5-Inch 32 GB Android UK SIM-Free Smartphone - Gold
review_text: I purchased this with low expectations due to previous SONY Phones, I got this to replace a Sony Xperia L that was damaged in a car crash and couldn't get repaired, so Insurance company advised I purchased the equivalent model hence Sony Xperia L2Had a long wait ordered mid-November did not arrive till end of December and then found the Micro SD Memory Slot did not function and would not retain the SD Card. Amazon replaced in a week and so far, new one is working very wellFindings5.5" LCD display - The display is nice and easy to read text and see pictures in most lights I only notice itâ€™s a 720p when put up against a Quad HD equipped Phone.Responsiveness of Touchscreen - my old Xperia L you had to use your finger and it occasionally was slow to respond and wouldn't work with any stylus or gloves so I am pleased to report the new one is quick and accurate to use and works with stylus for better typing (my fingers are a little big for some of the keyboards that come up when online)Performance/Chipset - I was not expecting much as I have read MediaTek are a cheaper processor and graphic chip set as they did not perform so well but I have found this responsive in normal use and not bad in a few games I have tried.Battery life - The Battery is lasting mainly just around a day but Sony's software to improve the Batteryâ€™s performance has only just started to learn my usage patterns and has on Two occasions extended the battery to one and a half days so may improve. The battery is sealed in the phone so user canâ€™t replace my Sony Xperia L had a removable one which means new L2 phone will have a shorter life.Fingerprint Sensor - this sensor is fast and easy to use and easy to set up and use making mobile banking and using the phone for shopping on line or in store more secure.Software Android 7.1.1 Nougat - This is fast and easy to use and doesn't have too much overlaid by Sony and little to no Bloatware some of Sonyâ€™s software apps are very good and easy to use I am not sure why but I got my Motorola Moto Z which had the Android 6 Marshmallow operating system(now on Android 8 Oreo) it allowed me to set up the SD Card as system memory (Friends Galaxy S7 edge does too)  which Sony doesn't  allow. Also must Question why Sony released the Xperia L2 in 2018 with 2016â€™s release 7.1.1 Nougat when all other phones were using 2017â€™s Android 8 Oreo and had no plans to upgrade the version of Android to 2017s Android 8 Oreo or 2018s 9 Pie ( I got 3 operating updates with my Nokia 700, Moto X and Moto Z and Motorola/Lenovo do one android update on competing Moto G range so not sure why Sony canâ€™t do one Version update).Sound - Speaker not bad for a bottom Mid-range phone very good when using headphones.Camera - front and back cameras take nice pictures and are easy to use.Build Quality Plastic and glass feels solid easy to hold and looks good has big strips at the top and bottom of screen which dates it, but I like itSummary a Good Entry Model to Smart phones with good build quality (you will want a phone case to protect it) but you can get similar or better specked Samsung and Motorola as well as others with newer software and for less money.ProsScreen Good colours and good and easy to see in most lightsTouchscreen Responsive and arcuateSD Memory card Expansion3.5 headphone jack - Good Sound on Head phonesCamera takes good quality photosResponsive to use with little bloatwareSony provide a Software program for Windows and Mac OS to Back up and Restore phone such as texts Email and programs and transferring things from other phones Sony and other makes e.g. Apple or Samsung. I backed up the faulty Sony Xperia L2 and it restored the settings from that to the replacement I was very impressed as my company Samsung GS6 back up wouldn't load backup to new phone after original died.ConsOut of date version of Android installed when launched and No chance of Sony Updating to newer more secure version.Missing Wi-Fi ACSony Do Not allow SD card to be set to be used as System Memory like other Makes.Battery Life for a 3300mah Battery driving a low power 720p screen and low power chip-set I would expect 2-3 light days use not the 1-1.5 I am getting.Screen only 720p at this price point and slightly lower are using 1080p.Support If you get a hardware fault Sony's Repair company in Kent are the biggest Rip off Merchants going (Photograph every angle of phone possible before sending it to them).

title: Sony Xperia XZ 5.2 inch 32 GB SIM-Free Smart Phone - Mineral Black
review_text: I am reviewing the XZ as I have had it for a few weeks now. The phone has surpassed all my expectations in every way.  I was using a z5 before and previous to my z5 I had a Z3 for 2 years. I will be comparing the XZ, z5/z3 and other phones I have used.Design The design has improved from the z3 and the z5, the phone feels solid and fits perfectly in your hand  , the metal back feels nice and solid, it is more durable than the glass back of the z3/ z5 and the corners are rounded too, making  it very comfortable in the hand. The screen has a rounded lip towards the edge, this is a nice touch and adds a degree of sophistication  to the design. There are enough design changes made to the XZ, that makes it look refreshing and different  from  the z5. It feels like a rolls Royce, solid and not light weight and flimsy like the Samsung s7 with its glass build.ScreenThe full 1080p 5.2 screen is sharp and vivid, the colours  are more natural and balanced than the over saturated colours of Samsung OLED screens. Comparing the Z5 and XZ the XZ brightness is  greater and the contrast is also better,  whites are more realistic than the z5. Having a full HD screen is an advantage because not only does it give you decent resolution it will put less stress on your processor, but will also preserve your battery life. This gives the ZX an advantage with phones with 2k screens.  Overall a very sharp glossy looking picture, it really stands out. I think Sony have coated their x series of phones screens with a glossy coating. The IPS panel  combined  with  the x reality pro engine ,which is used in there tvs , gives the XZ  one the best screens I've seen.PerformanceAs expected the Sony XZ is equipped with the latest snapdragon 820 chipset, with 3GB ram.The performance is rapid, smooth and without lag. The apps open instantly , browsers/ YouTube/casting/ and the camera instantly open. multitasking is excellent there is no lag. I would say it is about 15% faster than the previous snapdragon 810, Which my Z5 was equipped with. There is no overheating issues and the phone stays cool only getting slightly warm when gaming. When doing a side by side comparison with the z5, IE multi tasking, (app switching) the XZ was slightly faster  in every test i did, when compared with the z5. The z5 and XZ are very similar, in  day to day performance and there is not much  difference between them, and most people wouldn't notice , unless your were gaming.  Sony have the hardware and software tweaked very well.  The phone is equipped with 3gb ram, and it shows no lag, sony have optimized the phone really well,  Having 4/5 GB ram would only waste battery and  wouldn't make much difference to performance,  because android uses very little ram, the extra gig would be wasted. Sony take on android is clean with having very little bloatware. Its almost a stock android experience. One of the  new feature on this phone is  tip notifications, basically the phone learns your behaviour  and then trys to advise you by giving info on "how to take better pictures" etc. The Setup of the phone was so easy, basically I tapped my z5 and XZ together, all my goggle account, apps and contacts were ported over using NFC.  Overall the XZ performs  as good as any flagship from Samsung or htc, the big bonus is that the Sony  is cheaper than most flagships.Sound and CameraVoice calls are very clear , there is no distortion. Speakerphone is also clear  evan at loud volumes.The XZ supports hi res audio and LDAC Bluetooth compression. When streaming music to a wireless Bluetooth speaker, the sound quality is detailed  and clear with decent bass, LDAC seems to work and compression is kept to the minimum. The on-board stereo speakers are loud and clear , the stereo separation is done very well, the only negative point is that it does lack bass, but its a compromise  I can live with , due to the waterproofing of the speaker grills. Playing low quality MP3s are improved with DSEE HX UPSCALING and improves sound quality via audio jack or streaming or headphones. This is a accomplished music player. Camera quality has improved too , it has a new 23 megapixel sensor, what ever you throw at it you will see some of the best pictures a Smartphone can offer.  Not going to bore you with all the features and things this camera can do , but it is one impressive camera. Pictures are very detailed and  sharp, colours are natural, no oversaturation like I have seen on Samsung phones. The autofocus systems is fast you can take picture under a second without a blur.  This camera  is probably the best on the market. The Video quality is up there with the best, lots of detail  and real colours, i filmed a  1080p video of my 4 year old son playing in the park , the camera even picked up the individual whites stones in the tarmac. That's the sort detail were talking about.Battery life is about the same as my z5 just over a day and half , I like to way Sony have included a USB-C charging port, this will be the  standard soon and its good Sony have implemented the XZ with this, making it future proof, you can put the charging cable either way without breaking the usb port. I wish Sony had INCLUDED THE FAST CHARGER, They make you buy this separately.conclusionThe XZ is a accomplished phone it excels in all areas , everything is put together perfectly  in a single package , you have the best camera , best display, excellent build quality, waterproofing , Hi res audio . triple sensor camera, the list goes on. The XZ is also priced cheaper then all the current flagships. I would say if your looking for a quality waterproof android flagship, you wont be disappointed. If your upgrading  from a z3 or earlier, then this is a major improvement  and  worth going for. For Z5 owners i would say  its an improvement in the right areas  when comparing the z5 but not a massive one, if you happy with your z5 then  stick with it. if you can afford to upgrade to XZ then you will enjoy the new design and new features. The XZ is priced at Â£520 , not only is it cheaper then the S7 and apple iphone 7 but it offers all the specification, bell and whistle at lower price. Buy it with confidence and you wont go back.

title: Sony Xperia XZ 5.2 inch 32 GB SIM-Free Smart Phone - Mineral Black
review_title: Brilliant phone - Would still recommend in 2017 for those looking at an ex-flagship performance phone on a budget
review_text: Upgraded to this from an LG G2.In summary:- Design is great. Nice and slim but you might want to wack it in a case. (personal preference. A lot of people hate the Sony industrial look)- Fingerprint reader is snappy and makes life so much easier. I will never go back to a non fingerprint scanner phone.- OS has minimal bloatware. Whilst it does have some of the Sony apps on there it is not loaded with rubbish.- The Battery saver is sometimes annoying. occasionally it will not charge my phone in time for my wake up schedule. For the majority of time it is fairly intelligent and after a week or two of having the phone it understood my sleeping patterns well enough to be a minor nuisance. No idea if ti is a gimmick or not as I likely wont have the phone long enough to see if it actually extends the life of the battery!- Great screen. Hurts my eyeballs on max brightness and even having it set to 33% brightness I can forget that it is not on full- Sony quick with updates to the OSI have been a fan of Sony phones for a while. My last one was the Xperia Z1 that unfortunately went faulty. I purcahsed this for around Â£460 and it was worth the money. I think it will definitely hold up for a couple more years at least. With the recent launch of the ZX+ I believe the price will drop further making this a bargain!I cant comment on camera as I do not use it that much. Not had a problem running any apps and it does not seem to encounter the overheating issues that I have seen on the Z5 model.EDIT:Dec 2017 update.- Still going strong - SONY still smashing the updates to android - really great frequency of these.- Camera is not that great comapred to some of the phones out there now but still very good.- The battery saver now works perfectly and understand my routine - no problems with charging anymore.- Very rarely I do need a full reset to "refresh" the phone and make it feel like new again, perhaps once every 2 to 3 months. Apart from the occasional slowdown it is still very snappy and responsive.- no problems overheating
